dialogues.speaker: IN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Chris falters forward. Insurgents pursuing. The Stryker just visible ahead-- pulling away.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STRYKER
dialogues.text: M2 GUNNER can't see shit on his monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --stop the rig, man! Stop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see him--

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Chris is   ten feet behind the rig, sprinting. Bullets si past. He   sheds flack-jacket and webbing, Bible and flag He drops   his gun in the dirt and dives. His hand clutch the last   rung of slat-armor and-- Chris Kyle is dragged off the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Sand buries the METALLIC TOY SOLDIER that followed him since childhood. Wind whips pages of the Bible and pulls at the flag until it flaps unfolded. WE'RE BLOWN AWAY with it, twisting and clapping into an otherworldy beige.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STORM
dialogues.text: We catch glimpses of the city below: graffiti'd T-walls, a cracked expanse of desert floor and the lanky body of an enemy sniper splayed across a rooftop. Wind rips the Hefty bag away and sand pocks the DEAD FACE OF MUSTAFA-- before we're swept up into the howling rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS sits hunched at the bar, his eyes track patrons and staff (ECU) their hands, torsos, eyes. HIS PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? I got a weird message that you were on a plane? He can HEAR THE KIDS in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got out early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you in Germany, or--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, I'm stateside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're home? What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around for answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I just needed a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, the kids are dying to see you. It's been nine months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know... Me too. I'm coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then come home. We miss you. He nods silently, listens to his kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON- the back of Chris' head. He watches a WAR MOVIE on TV. As CAMERA CIRCLES the room, we glimpse THE MOVIE; an injured soldier calls for help amid shocking gunfire. TRACKING BEHIND THE TV, we see Chris' wrought face and a household bustling around him. COLTON carries party plates outside, MCKENNA fights to get cowboy boots on and TAYA CALLS to him from the kitchen but we can't hear her until the CAMERA TRACKS to HER POV-- the gunfire is gone, the TV IS OFF. That war movie is playing in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris...? He finally looks up, slick with sweat, affecting calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Streamers twist against gunmetal sky. COLTON and MCKENNA set up birthday decorations. The family dog, A PYRENEES SHEEPDOG, bounds about. TAYA AND CHRIS, on back steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --his game is Saturdays. He's the tallest kid on the team. The doctor said he could be six-four. I can't wait for you to see him play. Maybe you could even coach? Chris looks past his kids, looking a thousand yards out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKenna's about to lose that tooth and I'm worried she's going to swallow it. She said she'd let you pull it. But only you. His head falls. When he looks up--

dialogues.speaker: COLTON'S BIRTHDAY PARTY UNDERWAY
dialogues.text: 6 YEAR OLDS and PARENTS mill around but all WE HEAR--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd talk to me, Chris. COLTON AND TWO FRIENDS chase each other around the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel this dark space between us and I don't know how to reach you. THE SHEEPDOG jumps on the back of COLTON'S FRIEND. The boy goes down hard, gets up crying, running from the dog. The Sheepdog does it again. THE BOY FALLS AND HIS CRYING is cuts into scene. THE BOY'S MOM runs over. His back clawed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him off! Get away-- Chris rips the dog off by its collar. The dog snaps at him and in an instant he whips out his .45 to shoot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He's a puppy. He doesn't know! Chris looks up, bent with animus, and he's looking at the face of his children, their friends, and their parents-- They look at him, terrified. He releases the dog. Lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harsh light. Water-stained walls. CHRIS looks beaten, afraid and dubious of this BUTTONED-DOWN DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you saw things, or did some things over there that you wish you hadn't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's not you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just protecting my guys. They were trying to kill our soldiers and-- I'm willing to stand before my creator and answer for every shot I took. (struggles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing that haunts me are all the guys I couldn't save.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to save more guys, walk down any hall in this hospital. We got plenty soldiers that need saving. (pulls prescription pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to recommend Zoloft and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS steps to a window looking in on TEN YOUNG VETERANS sitting around a TV; wounded, edgy, in need. A legless Marine with a jelly-roll face looks up; this is "WYNN".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS kneels before WYNN (wheelchair) who's armed with a .300 resting on Chris' shoulder. Wynn takes aim, FIRES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels like The Legend is trying to fuck up my shot. Stay still, man. Gun on shoulder, Chris is calm, he's found peace. BAM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bulls-eye, boy! Damn, if that don't feel like I got my balls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris dusts himself off. There's healing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you spend all this time with us? I know you got a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you had a nice boot collection before the war and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously man. Why do you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta take care of our own. Chris squints into the falling sun and time passes with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black F350 roars past a "Welcome to Texas" sign on the interstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A residential neighborhood. Texas flags wave from stoops. CHRIS and COLTON carry boxes inside. "MAX THE SHEEPDOG" bounds along with them and never leaves Chris' side.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Chris enters to find Taya has placed his old COWBOY BOOTS at the foot of the bed. He takes a seat and looks down at the combat boots on his feet. He bends to unlace them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pale Stallion gallops through prairie grass. Chris and McKenna admire it from a rustic fence. Her pink cowboys boots kick Texas dust onto his old boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris is showering when Taya sneaks in and flushes the toilet. He howls at the scalding water and she's laughing, rushing for the door when-- he lunges out and grabs her, pulling her in with all her clothes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a watercolor dawn, CHRIS leads COLTON across a prairie, hunting rifle on shoulder, teaching as they go. THE SCORE BUILDS and follows them into morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust motes drift across blades of light falling through blinds onto CHRIS. He wears the BELT BUCKLE he won long ago, pleated Levis, and twirls an antique six-shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get `em up, lil' lady. Hands in the air. TAYA is at the window gazing at their kids in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell it to the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm proud of you and I don't say it enough. I feel blessed. You're an incredible father and-- I feel lucky to have my husband back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could lock the doors. They can't get out of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how hard you fought to get here. (03.18.14)                    115. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worth fighting for. She crosses to him, running a hand up his leg. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you pleat those jeans? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Right up the middle. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're just a regular old cowboy again, aren't you? He kisses her, lifting her-- CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant what I said about locking the doors. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you and Chad going to the range? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Not for four minutes. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all it takes. CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll take half that. Then I got two minutes leftover just to look at you. He sways with her, dancing a little two-step. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you taking out? CHRIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Marine. His mom does parking at school and she asked for my help. TAYA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't be late for dinner. COLTON and McKENNA race in, hugging on their dad. COLTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you want to play Skylander? Please--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go do something but when I get back, okay? But you have to let me win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poke the bear-- McKENNA pokes Chris and he BARKS like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're supposed to roar. Like Grrr. She pokes him again and Chris emits a RUMBLING ROAR. She giggles and hugs him so he'll save her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get going... He kisses his daughter and tosses his son's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look after our women, Bubba. (turns to Taya)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love you, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love you too. Chris kisses Taya and lingers, worshiping her. Dust motes drift past and he appears immortal in the bladed light. Then-- He walks out the door for the last time. The house grows quiet. Colton plays video games. McKenna colors. The dog lays by the door. And Taya stands in the golden light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARD(1): "On February 2, 2013, Chris Kyle was killed by a former Marine he was trying to help. He died as he lived... looking after one of his own."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls to Randy Travis singing Amazing Grace. (03.18.14)                        117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACTUAL FOOTAGE: A funeral procession appears over a distant ridge. Police escorts lead a white hearse and 300 vehicles down a highway lined with people waving flags. The last car finally passes. An UNKNOWN CIVILIAN stands alone in a muddy field saluting a fallen hero.
